tn.ref: Connecting Statement:
tn.text: Paul confirms that even in the past believers were made right with God by faith and not by the law.

tn.ref: What then will we say that Abraham, our forefather according to the flesh, found?
tn.text: Paul uses the question to catch the attention of the reader and to start talking about something new. AT: "This is what Abraham our physical ancestor found" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: For what does the scripture say
tn.text: Paul uses this question to add emphasis. He speaks of the Scriptures as if they were alive and could talk. AT: "For we can read in the scripture" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: and it was counted to him as righteousness
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "and God considered Abraham as a righteous person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Now for him who works, the recompense is not counted as grace, but as what is owed
tn.text: This describes a situation where a person who works expects to be paid for the work. That person does not consider payment a free gift or "grace."

tn.ref: recompense
tn.text: "wages" or "pay" or "what he earned by working"

tn.ref: what is owed
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "what his employer owes him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in the one who justifies
tn.text: "in God, who justifies"

tn.ref: his faith is counted as righteousness
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "God considers that person's faith as righteousness" or "God considers that person righteous because of his faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: David also pronounces blessing on the man to whom God counts righteousness without works
tn.text: "David also wrote about how God blesses the man whom God makes righteous without works"

tn.ref: whose iniquities are forgiven ... whose sins are covered ... against whom the Lord will not count sin
tn.text: The same concept is stated in three different ways. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "whose iniquities the Lord has forgiven ... whose sins the Lord has covered ... whose sins the Lord will not count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Then is this blessing pronounced only on those of the circumcision, or also on those of the uncircumcision?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to add emphasis. AT: "Does God bless only those who are circumcised, or also those who are not circumcised?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: those of the circumcision
tn.text: This is a metonym that refers to the Jewish people. AT: "the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: those of the uncircumcision
tn.text: This is a metonym that refers to the people who are not Jews. AT: "the Gentiles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Faith was counted to Abraham as righteousness
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "God considered the faith of Abraham as righteousness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: So how was it counted? When Abraham was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision?
tn.text: Paul asks these questions to add emphasis to his remarks. AT: "When did God consider Abraham to be righteous? Was it before his circumcision, or after it?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: It was not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision
tn.text: "It happened before he was circumcised, not after he was circumcised"

tn.ref: a seal of the righteousness of the faith that he had already possessed when he was in uncircumcision
tn.text: Here "righteousness of the faith" means that God considered him to be righteous. AT: "a visible sign that God considered him righteous because he had believed in God before he was circumcised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: even if they are in uncircumcision
tn.text: "even if they are not circumcised"

tn.ref: This means that righteousness will be counted for them
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "This means that God will consider them righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Abraham became the father of circumcision
tn.text: Here "circumcision" refers to those who are true believers in God, both Jews and Gentiles.

tn.ref: follow in the steps of our father Abraham
tn.text: Here "follow in the steps" is an idiom that means to follow the example of someone. AT: "follow the example of our father Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: that the promise was given to Abraham and to his descendants, this promise that they would be heirs of the world
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "that God promised to Abraham and his descendants that they would inherit the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: heirs
tn.text: The people to whom God has made promises are spoken of as if they were to inherit property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Instead, it was through the righteousness of faith
tn.text: The words "God gave the promise" are left out of this phrase but they are understood. You can translate this by adding these implied words. AT: "Instead, God gave the promise through faith which he considers as righteousness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: if those belonging to the law are heirs
tn.text: Here "belonging to the law" means those who obey the law. AT: "if it is those who obey the law that will inherit the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: faith is made empty, and the promise is nullified
tn.text: "faith has no value and the promise is meaningless"

tn.ref: but where there is no law, neither is there disobedience
tn.text: You can translate this double negative in a positive form. AT: "but where there is no law, there is nothing to disobey" or "because there is something for people to disobey only where there is law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: For this reason this happens by faith, so that it might be by grace
tn.text: Here "grace" refers to God's free gift. AT: "Here is the reason we receive the promise when we trust God: it is so that it might be a free gift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: As a result, the promise is sure for all the descendants
tn.text: "So that all the descendants of Abraham might certainly receive the promise"

tn.ref: those who know the law
tn.text: This refers to the Jewish people who follow the law of Moses.

tn.ref: those who are from Abraham's faith
tn.text: This refers to those who have faith like Abraham did before he was circumcised.

tn.ref: father of us all
tn.text: Here the word "us" refers to Paul and includes all Jewish and non-Jewish believers in Christ. Abraham is the physical ancestor of the Jewish people, but he is also the spiritual father of those who have faith. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: as it is written
tn.text: Where it is written can be made explicit. You can also translate this in an active form. AT: "as someone has written in the Scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I have made you
tn.text: Here the word "you" is singular and refers to Abraham. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Abraham was in the presence of him whom he trusted, that is, God, who gives life to the dead
tn.text: Here "of him whom he trusted" refers to God. AT: "Abraham was in the presence of God whom he trusted, who gives life to those who have died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: calls the things that do not exist into existence
tn.text: "created everything from nothing"

tn.ref: Despite all outward circumstances
tn.text: The full meaning of "outward circumstances" can be made explicit. AT: "Even though it seemed impossible for him to have descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: So he became the father of many nations
tn.text: "And the result of Abraham's faith was that he became the father of many nations"

tn.ref: according to what had been spoken
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "just as God said to Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Thus will be your descendants
tn.text: The full promise God gave to Abraham can be made explicit. AT: "You will have more descendants than you can count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He was not weak in faith
tn.text: You can translate this in a positive form. AT: "He remained strong in his faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: did not hesitate in unbelief
tn.text: You can translate this double negative in a positive form. AT: "kept on acting in faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: he was strengthened in faith
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "he became stronger in his faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: He was fully convinced
tn.text: "Abraham was completely sure"

tn.ref: he was also able to accomplish
tn.text: "God was able to do"

tn.ref: Therefore this was also counted to him as righteousness
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "Therefore God counted Abraham's belief as righteousness" or "Therefore God considered Abraham righteous because Abraham believed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Now it was
tn.text: "Now" is used here to connect Abraham's being made right by faith to present-day believer's being made right by faith in Christ's death and resurrection.

tn.ref: only for his benefit
tn.text: "for Abraham only"

tn.ref: that it was counted for him
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "that God counted righteousness to him" or "God considered him righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: for us
tn.text: The word "us" refers to Paul and includes all believers in Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: It was written also for us, for whom it will be counted, we who believe
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "It was also for our benefit, because God will consider us righteous also if we believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: him who raised
tn.text: "God, who raised"

tn.ref: This is the one who was delivered up for our trespasses
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "This is the one whom God handed over to those who killed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: and was raised for our justification
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "and whom God brought back to life so God could make us right with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
